description:
Waking up in a strange virtual world with no recollection of the past, Hakuno finds himself forced to fight for survival in a war he does not understand for a prize beyond value; the opportunity to have one's wish granted. With only an enigmatic "Servant" by his side, Hakuno Kishinami will have to face both friends and foes in battles to the death in order to not only gain possession of a mysterious object known as the "Holy Grail," but also to find the answer to the most important question of all: "Who am I?"

Notes:
- Includes episodes 11-13, Illustrias Geocentric Theory.
- The last episode aired with a runtime of 48 minutes as opposed to the standard 24.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Spearplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of spears in combat.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Amnesia
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) with memory loss.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Magic
tags.description: Prominently features magical elements or the use of magic.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

node.description:
__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

A Japanese author best known for writing the visual novels Tsukihime and Fate/stay night. Renowned for a unique style of storytelling and prose, Nasu is amongst the most prominent visual novelists in Japan. 

Together with high school classmate and friend, [Takeuchi Takashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi), Nasu formed [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582) in 2000, originally as a doujin group to create the visual novel Tsukihime. It soon gained immense popularity, much of which is attributed to Nasu's unique style of storytelling. A sequel to Tsukihime, Kagetsu Tohya, was released on August 2001. 

54563 Kinokonasu is named after him

__Headquarters:__ Tokyo, Japan

__[Website](http://typemoon.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/tmitterofficial)__

__Introduction:__
Type-Moon is a Japanese game company was founded by artist [Takashi Takeuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi) and writer [Kinoko Nasu](https://anilist.co/staff/98250/Kinoko-Nasu), who were also schoolmates. The names "TYPE-MOON" and "Notes." come from one of their early works, Notes..

__History:__
Originally formed as a Doujin Soft in 2000 and created the popular visual novel Tsukihime, but turned into a Commercial Organization on January 30, 2004 and in the same year, they released their PC-based eroge visual novel game Fate/stay night, which is their most well known title.

**Birthplace:** Fukuoka, Japan

Yukihiro Miyamoto, occasionally nicknamed Otokomatsuri, is a Japanese animator and director. He started at animation studio Vega Entertainment, and later joined Shaft. He is best known for directing Puella Magi Madoka Magica and its subsequent film trilogy alongside Akiyuki Shinbo, the latter trilogy which subsequently garnered ¥2 billion, making it a box-office success.

Miyamoto described himself as being a "heretic" at Shaft-- someone who, in a company of many differing directors, is only good at doing "plain work", and isn't particularly original or creative. Shinbo described Miyamoto in a similar way, but said that he was more like a professional craftsman who leaves their mark in places that cannot be seen.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/新房昭之) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akiyuki_Shinbo)

Akiyuki Shinbou is a Japanese director, producer, animator and storyboard artist. He joined Studio One Pattern in 1981. He made his directorial debut with [Metal Fighter Miku](https://anilist.co/anime/1175/) in 1994. He joined Shaft in 2004. He has received the 11th Tokyo Anime Award and the 2011 Newtype Anime Award for Best director for his work on the acclaimed anime series [Puella Magi Madoka Magica](https://anilist.co/anime/9756/).

Shinbou was born in Fukushima Prefecture. After high school, he attended Tokyo Designer Institute before entering the anime industry.

After graduating from Tokyo Design Institute, Shinbou worked as an animator for the 1981 anime series [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/). Shinbou participated with Studio Pierrot in 1990 as an episode director in [Musashi](https://anilist.co/anime/8065/). His first full directorial debut was however the previously mentioned, with Metal Fighter Miku. He continued his early directional career with several OVA series in the late 90's. Shinbou participated with Seven Arcs starting with [Triangle Heart: Sweet Songs Forever](https://anilist.co/anime/176/) in 2003 and then became director for 2004's spin-off [Magical Girl Lyrical Nanoha](https://anilist.co/anime/76/).

His style in particular became noticed during his episode direction work on [Yu Yu Hakusho](https://anilist.co/anime/392/)'s Dark Tournament arc. After seeing Shinbou's stylized presence, the new president of Shaft, [Mitsutoshi Kubota](https://anilist.co/staff/151830/), approached Shinbou with the desire to make Shaft a distinctive studio among animation companies. In an interview, Kubota cited [Le Portrait de Petit Cossette](https://anilist.co/anime/514/) and [The SoulTaker](https://anilist.co/anime/1048/) among Shinbou's most distinctive products that caught his eye.

His work at Shaft has been characterized by extensive experimentation within the visual medium of animation, and often includes pictures taken from real life cut into scenes, as well as art shifts, beat panels, kabuki sound effects, textures that remain stationary when the textured object moves, showing symbols or defining parts of a character in place of characters during dialogue, written text in place (in opposition to dialogue), precise use of fan service, and "head-tilting", a style known as a Shaft specialty.

He says that the reason he sticks with Shaft is due to their system and professional capacity, which make his expression of direction much easier. The so-called "Team Shinbou" includes himself, [Tatsuya Oishi](https://anilist.co/staff/103552/) and [Shin Oonuma](https://anilist.co/staff/101753/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

A Japanese composer and arranger. He joined NAMCO as a soundtrack composer in 1999, and then he joined MONACA Inc. as a music designer in 2004.

Soundtracks he has worked on credited as MONACA: 
- Star Driver: Kagayaki no Takuto (with Keigo Hoashi and Ryuichi Takada) 
- Hourou Musuko (with Keigo Hoashi and Keiichi Okabe) 
- A-Channel (with Kakeru Ishihama, Ryuichi Takada, Keigo Hoashi)

__[Website](https://www.sayuri-official.com/)__ | __[Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1wLdD1RVGp_rLH1NRJnD0A)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/taltalasuka)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sayuri149cm/)__

Sanketsu Shoujo Sayuri (lit. "Suffocating girl Sayuri") was a Japanese singer, musician and songwriter, signed under Ariola Japan.
Sayuri labeled herself as a 2.5D-parallel singer/songwriter, meaning she expressed herself through the internet in the 2D world and through live performances in the 3D world. 
For her 2D appearance she created various characters, mainly used in her music videos. While they all bear the name of Sayuri, each character's name differentiates itself by a different mix of Hiragana and Katakana (さゆり, サユリ, サゆり).

Sayuri made her major debut with the single "[Mikazuki](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=65BAeDpwzGY)", which was used as the ending theme to the Fuji TV anime "[Ranpo Kitan: Game of Laplace](https://anilist.co/anime/21189/Ranpo-Kitan-Game-of-Laplace/)".  Her first full-length album “Mikazuki no Kokai”, released May 17, 2017, debuted at #1 on Oricon’s daily album chart.

Sayuri announced her marriage to the vocalist and composer Ama Arashi (from the music group Misekai) on March 18th, 2024.

On September 27, 2024, her husband posted [an announcement](https://x.com/taltalasuka/status/1839500307094450552) on her X/Twitter account that she had passed away on September 20, 2024 at the age of 28.

[Website](https://monaca.jp/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_jp)

__MONACA__ is a Japanese music production studio, which was established by the composer Keiichi Okabe in October 2004.

__Members__:
• [Keiichi Okabe](https://anilist.co/staff/121585/Keiichi-Okabe) (CEO)
• [Satoru Kousaki](https://anilist.co/staff/101555/Satoru-Kousaki)
• [Ryuuichi Takada](https://anilist.co/staff/109459/Ryuuichi-Takada)
• [Kakeru Ishihama](https://anilist.co/staff/150946/Kakeru-Ishihama)
• [Hidekazu Tanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/141852/Hidekazu-Tanaka)
• [Keiichi Hirokawa](https://anilist.co/staff/156490/Keiichi-Hirokawa)
• [Kuniyuki Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/154774/Kuniyuki-Takahashi)
• [Shuotarou Seo](https://anilist.co/staff/317330/Shoutarou-Seo)
• [Oliver Good](https://anilist.co/staff/317296)
• [Keita Inoue](https://anilist.co/staff/229376/Keita-Inoue)

__Past Members__:
• [Yuri Mitsumi](https://anilist.co/staff/201236/Yuri-Misumi)
• [Keigo Hoashi](https://anilist.co/staff/111233/Keigo-Hoashi)

__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

A Japanese author best known for writing the visual novels Tsukihime and Fate/stay night. Renowned for a unique style of storytelling and prose, Nasu is amongst the most prominent visual novelists in Japan. 

Together with high school classmate and friend, [Takeuchi Takashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi), Nasu formed [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582) in 2000, originally as a doujin group to create the visual novel Tsukihime. It soon gained immense popularity, much of which is attributed to Nasu's unique style of storytelling. A sequel to Tsukihime, Kagetsu Tohya, was released on August 2001. 

54563 Kinokonasu is named after him

Hikaru was formerly an in-house writer for the eroge company Liar-soft and now is a freelance novelist.

[Website](http://sakuraihikaru.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/h_sakura)

**Birthplace:** Fukuoka, Japan

Yukihiro Miyamoto, occasionally nicknamed Otokomatsuri, is a Japanese animator and director. He started at animation studio Vega Entertainment, and later joined Shaft. He is best known for directing Puella Magi Madoka Magica and its subsequent film trilogy alongside Akiyuki Shinbo, the latter trilogy which subsequently garnered ¥2 billion, making it a box-office success.

Miyamoto described himself as being a "heretic" at Shaft-- someone who, in a company of many differing directors, is only good at doing "plain work", and isn't particularly original or creative. Shinbo described Miyamoto in a similar way, but said that he was more like a professional craftsman who leaves their mark in places that cannot be seen.

__[Website](http://www.tm-revolution.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/TMR15) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/takanori9nishikawa/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/tmrevolutionofficial)__

Takanori Nishikawa is a Japanese voice actor, vocalist, lyricist, composer and arranger, who made his debut in the name of T.M.Revolution (T.M.R.) in May 1996, with a single “Dokusai –monopolize-”. Since then, he has established a reputation as a singer with ear-catching tunes, intriguing, irresistible and perfect stage setting and live performances. Many singles have been picked up for theme of major animations and games including “Mobile Suit Gundam”, and “Sengoku BASARA”. Since debut, T.M.R. has built global fan base and reputation mainly among Japanimation fans. He has performed at major anime conventions in the US, such as OTAKON 2003 (@ Baltimore, MD, August 2003), Pacific Media Expo (@ Anaheim, CA and other cities, May 2004) and the local audience were dazzled by his dynamic performance. 

These activities led to his release of albums worldwide. T.M.R. launched his 10th anniversary project in 2005. He released single “vestige” in August 2005 charting No.1 on Oricon chart (Japanese version of Billboard) and released a self-cover album “UNDER:COVER” (all songs are requested by fans) in January 2006. In June, he released a CD and a DVD, both entitled “1000000000000”(pronounced billion) featuring all singles and music videos he had released until then and ranked NO.1 on Oricon chart. Also, T.M.R. went back to the US by appearing on stage for New York Comic Convention, the largest pop culture convention on April 19th 2008 in NYC. On September 19th 2012, T.M.R. released DVD and Blu-ray disc “T.M.R. LIVE REVOLUTION '12 -15th Anniversary FINAL-” which contains footage of 15th anniversary tour final at Daiichi-Taiikukan, National Yoyogi Stadium in Tokyo. On September 2012, he organized a huge open-air rock festival “Inazuma Rock Festival” for the fourth time in his birth place Shiga prefecture. He will be participating “Anime Festival Asia 2012” in Singapore in November. He’s currently expanding his field as an actor, voice actor, and host for a media program.

(Source: tm-revolution.com)

__Non-anime roles:__
- Arataki Itto - Genshin Impact (VG)

Originating from [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/). Directs on rare occasions.

Worked for Square Enix in Honolulu, Hawaii together with [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/) and others for the first decade of the 2000s and was completely absent from the anime industry because of this. Returned in 2011 and has been active since.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/the_red_scanner) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/古賀一臣)

Started off doing finishing work at J.C. Staff.
